abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Transport Infrastructure
            Investment Project (TIIP) for Madagascar were as follows:
            outcomes were moderately satisfactory, risk to development
            outcome was high, Bank performance was moderately
            satisfactory, and Borrower performance was moderately
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: two of the
            reasons why the transport sector reforms in general and the
            ports and airports concession in particular were not
            entirely successful were: (i) the high-level political
            interference in the sector, and (ii) the overambitious
            target to concession all the ports and airports in the
            country. The instability risk raises the question about the
            adequacy of the Adaptable Program Loan (APL) instruments
            which were designed to support a long-term transport sector
            transformational agenda. The choice of the Project
            Development Objective (PDO) indicators should take into
            account the type of data which can be collected during
            implementation. The Monitoring and Evaluation (M and E)
            system of the TIIP did not make clear distinction between
            the achievements under: (a) the standalone project; (b) the
            APL series; and (c) the government long-term program. As a
            result, it was not easy to assess the achievements, the
            outcomes and the impacts of the project. Some sections had
            to be rehabilitated or reconstructed contributing to a
            higher cost than anticipated. Proactivity and innovation
            during project implementation are necessary to adapting to
            an ever changing environment. While supporting railway
            concession, ensure enabling environment and fair intermodal competition.
